```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )

      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {

                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
```

Below are the changes highlighted for the relevant portion of the code:

1. Amend the `init` function in the `AxisSecondary` to check if the scale is discrete and breaks have names. If so, set the labels to these names if they are not already specified.

Here's the updated section of the file:

```r
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    
    # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks

    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }

    # Check if breaks have names and use as labels if applicable
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$labels <- names(self$breaks)
        # If breaks have names, use names as labels
        if (is.null(self$labels)) {
          self$labels <- scale$labels
        }
      } else {
        self$labels <- scale$labels
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  # (rest of the code remains unchanged)

```

### Explanation
- In the `init` function, after determining the `breaks`, we check if `self$labels` is derived.
- If the scale is discrete, we set `self$labels` to the names of the `breaks` if they exist. If the names are `NULL`, we fall back to using the labels from the primary axis.
- This ensures that named breaks for discrete scales will be displayed as labels on the secondary axis by default.

```
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
```

```
    else {
      breaks <- setNames(scale$map(self$breaks), names(self$breaks))
    }
```

That's all that's needed, but both changes are needed.

```
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'

#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
```

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
samples.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
To solve this problem using tidyverse, we can follow these steps:

1. Filter the `flights` data to include flights with at least 100 occurrences of each `tailnum`.
2. Calculate the proportion of NA `arr_delay` for each `tailnum`.
3. Identify the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`.

Here is the tidyverse code to achieve this:

```r
library(tidyverse)

# Find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delay, having flown at least 100 flights
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Filter groups with at least 100 flights
  filter(n() >= 100) %>%
  # Summarize to calculate the proportion of NA in arr_delay
  summarize(proportion_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))) %>%
  # Arrange in descending order of proportion_na_arr_delay to find the max
  arrange(desc(proportion_na_arr_delay)) %>%
  # Select the top result
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select the tailnum for the result
  select(tailnum, proportion_na_arr_delay)
```

Ensure that the `flights` data frame is available in your R environment before running the code. The `slice` function is used here to select the top `tailnum` based on the calculated proportion of missing values in `arr_delay`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
To find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s and has flown at least 100 flights, you can use the following `tidyverse` code:

```r
library(dplyr)

# Calculate the proportion of NA `arr_delay` for each `tailnum`
result <- flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarise(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    na_proportion = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  select(tailnum, na_proportion)

print(result)
```

Here's a breakdown of what this code does:
- The code groups the `flights` data by `tailnum`.
- It calculates the total number of flights (`total_flights`) and the count of NA `arr_delay`s (`na_arr_delays`) for each `tailnum`.
- It computes the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s for each `tailnum`.
- It filters to include only those `tailnum`s that have been involved in at least 100 flights.
- It arranges the results in descending order of the NA proportion and selects the tailnum with the highest value.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
To find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights, you can use the `dplyr` and `tidyverse` packages to manipulate and filter the data. Here's the tidyverse code to achieve this:

```r
library(dplyr)

# Calculate the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delay for flights with at least 100 flights
highest_na_tailnum <- flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%                             # Group by tailnum
  summarise(total_flights = n(),                     # Count total flights
            na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),   # Count NA arr_delays
            proportion_na = na_arr_delays / total_flights) %>%  # Calculate proportion of NA arr_delays
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%                  # Filter tailnums with at least 100 flights
  arrange(desc(proportion_na)) %>%                  # Sort by highest proportion of NA
  slice(1)                                          # Select the first row

highest_na_tailnum
```

This code performs the following steps:
1. Groups the data by `tailnum`.
2. Summarizes each group to count the total number of flights, the number of `NA` `arr_delay`s, and calculates the proportion of `NA` `arr_delay`s.
3. Filters the results to only include `tailnum`s that have flown at least 100 flights.
4. Arranges the filtered results by the highest proportion of `NA` `arr_delay`s.
5. Selects the top result to get the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of `NA` values.

messages.content:
I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

How do I fix it?

content.text:
The error you are encountering in R indicates that there is a mismatch in dimensions when trying to use the `.by` argument inside the `mutate()` function. The `.by` argument is used in functions from the `dplyr` package to specify grouping variables for certain operations, but it's important to use it correctly to avoid such errors.

Let's review the possible reasons for this error and how you can fix it:

1. **Ensure Correct Usage of `.by`:**
   The error seems to indicate that you might be trying to use `.by` for a purpose it is not intended for, or that you are misunderstanding its usage within `mutate()`. As of my last update, the commonly used way to perform operations by group in `dplyr` is by using `group_by()`.

   Example:
   ```r
   library(dplyr)

   df <- df %>%
       group_by(id, date) %>%
       mutate(new_column = some_operation()) %>%
       ungroup()
   ```

2. **Check for Correct Grouping:**
   Make sure that your grouping columns (`id` and `date` in your case) are of appropriate types and that they actually exist in your dataframe. A mismatch or incorrect assumption about your data can lead to unexpected dimensions.

3. **Examine Dataframe Dimensions:**
   Scrutinize the dimensions before and after using mutate. You should ensure that `mutate()` is adding the expected number of columns and that any generated columns adhere to the constraints of dataframe dimensions.

4. **Length Consistency:**
   Ensure that the result of `some_operation()` (or whatever function you are using inside `mutate()`) results in a proper length and that its output aligns correctly for each group.

If you could provide more context or code details, a more specific solution could be offered. However, using `group_by()` in combination with `mutate()` should address most of the issues related to your current approach with `.by`.

content.text:
The error message you are encountering in R indicates a problem with the size of the `by` argument inside the `mutate()` function. The error suggests that the `by` argument is expected to have a certain size, but the provided one doesn't match the requirement.

Here's a step-by-step guide to troubleshoot and fix the issue:

### Context and Understanding:

1. **`mutate()` Function:**
   - The `mutate()` function in the `dplyr` package is used to add new variables or modify existing ones in a data frame.

2. **`by` Argument:**
   - The `by` argument is typically used with functions like `left_join()`, `right_join()`, `inner_join()`, or `full_join()`, but not with `mutate()`. Therefore, using `by` inside `mutate()` is likely a misunderstanding or a misplacement of the argument.

### Steps to Fix:

1. **Review the Code:**
   - Ensure the logic you want to achieve is correctly structured. If you're trying to add or modify columns based on grouping, consider using `group_by()` before `mutate()`.
   
2. **Identify Correct Use-Cases:**
   - If you're attempting to perform operations that depend on grouping:
     ```R
     library(dplyr)

     df <- df %>%
       group_by(id, date) %>%
       mutate(new_var = some_operation())
     ```
   - Replace `some_operation()` with the actual computation you are performing.

3. **If Joining is Intended:**
   - If your goal is to join another data frame based on `id` and `date`, then use `join` functions like `left_join()`, etc.
     ```R
     df <- df1 %>%
       left_join(df2, by = c("id", "date"))
     ```

4. **Check Data Consistency:**
   - Ensure that `id` and `date` columns are properly defined in your data frames and do not have duplicate rows which might cause unexpected sizes.

5. **Correct Misplacement in Code:**
   - If `by` was incorrectly placed in `mutate()` due to a copy-paste error or misunderstanding, remove it and redefine your logic.

### Conclusion:

Once you've validated the logic and corrected the use of the `by` argument, your error should be resolved. Always double-check the function you are applying and its associated arguments to ensure compatibility within your data manipulation operations in R.

content.text:
The error you're encountering when using `.by` inside `mutate()` suggests that there is a mismatch in the sizes of the vectors you're trying to work with. In `dplyr`, the `.by` argument is used to specify grouping, similar to using `group_by()`, and it helps in performing operations within those groups without explicitly calling `group_by()`.

Here's how you can address the error and ensure your code works correctly:

1. **Ensure Column Names Are Correct**: Double-check that `id` and `date` are the correct column names in your dataset. Any typos or incorrect column names could cause issues.

2. **Check for Correct Use of `.by`**: Make sure that you're using `.by` inside `mutate()` appropriately. The `.by` argument should contain the names of the grouping columns as a character vector.

3. **Use Correct Syntax**: Here's an example syntax of how `.by` should be used within `mutate()`:

    ```r
    library(dplyr)

    df <- df %>%
      mutate(new_column = some_function(existing_column), .by = c("id", "date"))
    ```

   Make sure that `some_function(existing_column)` is compatible with your data and does not return a larger vector than the number of rows in each group.

4. **Check for Expandability within Groups**: The operation you're performing should ensure that the new column's length matches the number of rows within each group specified by `.by`. This error could occur if the function you're using inside `mutate()` returns a size that doesn't align with each group's row count defined by your `by` variables.

5. **Reduce Complexity**: If the above steps dont resolve the issue, separate your operations by explicitly using `group_by()`:

    ```r
    df <- df %>%
      group_by(id, date) %>%
      mutate(new_column = some_function(existing_column)) %>%
      ungroup()
    ```

6. **Inspect Your Data**: Double-check your data to ensure there are no unexpected duplicates or structural issues affecting group sizes.

These steps should help you address the `.by` related error in your `mutate()` function. If the problem persists, examine the specific function used inside `mutate()` and ensure it's appropriate for grouped operations.

content.text:
To achieve this, you can modify the `task_create` function to include a `name` argument that defaults to the name of the `dataset` object in the calling environment. This involves capturing the expression provided for `dataset` and evaluating it to get the object name. Here's how you can implement it:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  # Add 'dir' and 'name' attributes to the result
  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

### Explanation:

- **`name = deparse(substitute(dataset))`:** 
  - `substitute(dataset)`: This captures the expression provided to the `dataset` argument without evaluating it. This is useful to get the textual representation of the argument as provided by the user.
  - `deparse(...)`: This converts the captured expression into a character string. This string represents the name of the `dataset` as it appears in the calling environment.
  
- **Attribute storage:**
  - After creating the structure for `res`, we add an attribute `name` set to the evaluated name of `dataset`.
  
With this setup, if you call `task_create(dataset = eval)`, the `name` attribute in the returned object `x` will be `"eval"`.

To achieve this, you can modify the `task_create` function to include a `name` argument that defaults to the name of the `dataset` object in the calling environment. This involves capturing the expression provided for `dataset` and evaluating it to get the object name. Here's how you can implement it:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  # Add 'dir' and 'name' attributes to the result
  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

### Explanation:

- **`name = deparse(substitute(dataset))`:** 
  - `substitute(dataset)`: This captures the expression provided to the `dataset` argument without evaluating it. This is useful to get the textual representation of the argument as provided by the user.
  - `deparse(...)`: This converts the captured expression into a character string. This string represents the name of the `dataset` as it appears in the calling environment.
  
- **Attribute storage:**
  - After creating the structure for `res`, we add an attribute `name` set to the evaluated name of `dataset`.
  
With this setup, if you call `task_create(dataset = eval)`, the `name` attribute in the returned object `x` will be `"eval"`.

samples.input: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?
samples.target: Either set `geom_jitter(height = 0)` or `geom_point(position = position_jitter(height = 0))`.

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
To jitter points only along the x-axis in ggplot2, you can use the `position_jitter()` function with the `width` parameter set to your desired jitter amount and the `height` parameter set to 0. This will ensure that only the x values are jittered while the y values remain unchanged.

Here's an example of how you can do this:

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Create some example data
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  x = rep(1:3, each = 10),
  y = rnorm(30)
)

# Create a ggplot
p <- ggplot(data, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)) +
  theme_minimal()

# Display the plot
print(p)
```

In this example, `position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)` ensures that the points are jittered only along the x-axis with a jitter width of 0.2 units. You can adjust the `width` parameter to control the amount of jittering according to your needs.

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
In ggplot2, you can jitter points only along the x-axis by using the `position_jitter()` function with specific arguments for the width and height. You will set the `width` argument to a non-zero value to jitter along the x-axis and the `height` argument to zero to keep the y values unchanged.

Here's an example of how you can achieve this:

```R
# Load ggplot2
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
set.seed(42)
df <- data.frame(
  x = rep(1:3, each = 10),
  y = rnorm(30)
)

# Create a ggplot with jittered points on the x-axis only
ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

In this code:

- `df` is a sample data frame with x and y values.
- `aes(x = x, y = y)` specifies the aesthetic mappings for x and y.
- `geom_point()` is used to create the scatter plot.
- `position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)` is used to apply jittering only to the x-axis. The `width` argument controls the degree of horizontal jittering, and the `height` argument is set to 0 to maintain the original y values.

Adjust the `width` value as needed to control the amount of jitter along the x-axis.

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

input.content:
In ggplot2, you can jitter points only along the x-axis by using the `position_jitter()` function with specific arguments for the width and height. You will set the `width` argument to a non-zero value to jitter along the x-axis and the `height` argument to zero to keep the y values unchanged.

Here's an example of how you can achieve this:

```R
# Load ggplot2
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
set.seed(42)
df <- data.frame(
  x = rep(1:3, each = 10),
  y = rnorm(30)
)

# Create a ggplot with jittered points on the x-axis only
ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

In this code:

- `df` is a sample data frame with x and y values.
- `aes(x = x, y = y)` specifies the aesthetic mappings for x and y.
- `geom_point()` is used to create the scatter plot.
- `position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)` is used to apply jittering only to the x-axis. The `width` argument controls the degree of horizontal jittering, and the `height` argument is set to 0 to maintain the original y values.

Adjust the `width` value as needed to control the amount of jitter along the x-axis.

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
If you want to jitter points in a ggplot2 plot only along the x-axis while keeping the y values unchanged, you can use the `position_jitter()` function in combination with `geom_point()`. The `position_jitter()` function allows you to specify the amount of jittering separately for the x and y axes. To jitter only on the x-axis, you set the jitter width for x and set the height for y to zero.

Here's a basic example of how you can achieve this:

```R
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
df <- data.frame(
  x = rep(1:5, each = 10),
  y = rnorm(50)
)

# Create the plot with jitter on the x-axis only
ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)) +
  theme_minimal()
```

In this example:

- `position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)`: Jitters the data points along the x-axis by a small amount (0.2) and keeps the points at the same y-value by setting the height to 0.

Adjust the `width` parameter to control the amount of jitter. The value `0.2` is just an example; you may need to adjust this value depending on your specific dataset and the desired amount of jitter.

I have some code

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
...
}
```

I'd like the default name to be the symbol referring to the dataset, e.g. in

```
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- 
  task_create(
    dataset = simple_addition
  )
```

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?
samples.target: The `name` default is evaluated lazily, and something else results in `dataset` being evaluated before `name` is. `name` must be evaluated early in the function, e.g. using `force(name)`.

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?

content.text:
The issue you're experiencing is due to the use of `deparse(substitute(dataset))` within the `task_create` function, which is evaluated before the function actually uses its arguments. This results in `name` being assigned the entire structure of the dataset rather than the symbol name `simple_addition`.

To correctly capture the symbol name of the dataset rather than its contents, you can make use of non-standard evaluation (NSE) techniques available in R. Specifically, you can use `substitute()` to capture the expression and `deparse()` it into a character string. Here's how you can adjust your function:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = substitute(dataset),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # Convert the expression to a character string
  name <- deparse(name)
  
  # Now you can proceed with the rest of your function's logic
  # For demonstration purposes only
  message("Creating a task with name: ", name)
  
  # Continue with actual logic
  # ...
}

# Example usage
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- task_create(
  dataset = simple_addition
)
```

In the adjusted code, `substitute()` captures the expression for the actual argument passed to `dataset` (i.e., `simple_addition`), and `deparse()` converts that expression into a string which represents the symbol name. This ensures that `name` gets set to `"simple_addition"` by default when the task is created.

To ensure you get the name of the variable passed as the argument, you can slightly modify how you capture the name within the function. Heres a way to do it:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = as.character(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # Use 'name' as a string for the name of the dataset

    # Rest of your function code goes here...
}
```

```r
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- task_create(dataset = simple_addition)
```

will result in the `name` being correctly set to `"simple_addition"`. The key here is to ensure that `substitute()` is capturing just the variable name you pass in rather than the entire expression. This is effectively done by converting the substituted expression directly to a character string with `as.character()`.

content.text:
The issue you're encountering stems from the fact that `deparse(substitute(dataset))` generates an expression that represents the dataset, which can include more than just the variable name, especially when the dataset is complex or a result of an expression. To retrieve only the variable name as a string, you can use `substitute` to capture the expression passed to the `task_create` function and then convert it to a string using `deparse`.

Heres how you can modify the function to achieve what you want:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # Only take the first element of the deparsed string
    # to avoid evaluating complex expressions
    name <- if(is.character(name)) name[1] else name
    
    # Rest of your function logic here
    # ...
}

library(tibble)

simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- task_create(
  dataset = simple_addition
)

print(tsk)
```

### Explanation:

1. **`substitute(dataset)`**: Captures the expression `simple_addition`.
2. **`deparse(substitute(dataset))`**: Converts the expression into a human-readable string, resulting in "simple_addition".
3. **`name[1]`**: Ensures that only the first part of the deparsed result is used, which is usually sufficient unless the expression is extremely complex.

With this setup, whenever you pass a dataset like `simple_addition`, the default `name` will be "simple_addition".

samples.input:
I have an R package that depends on a package called, lets say, spatialstuff (This is how it is defined in its DESCRIPTIONS). However it is found in an org and the repo name is different, eg org/spatial-Stuff (i have no control over this name!).

My package in its `DESCRIPTION` file has the following lines

```
Imports:
 spatialstuff
Remotes:
 org/spatial-Stuff
```

However the `pkgdown.yaml` workflow that is run upon pushes (created from `usethis::use_pkgdown_github_pages()`) errors with the following message.

Can someone explain if this is user error or some other error? Thanks

```
! error in pak subprocess
Caused by error:
! Could not solve package dependencies:
deps::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* spatialstuff: Can't find package called spatialstuff.
* local::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* any::sessioninfo: dependency conflict
* any::pkgdown: dependency conflict
```
samples.target: The user needs to specify the package name explicitly in the Remotes `DESCRIPTION` field using a `<package>=` prefix, e.g. `spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff`.

messages.content:
I have an R package that depends on a package called, lets say, spatialstuff (This is how it is defined in its DESCRIPTIONS). However it is found in an org and the repo name is different, eg org/spatial-Stuff (i have no control over this name!).

My package in its `DESCRIPTION` file has the following lines

```
Imports:
 spatialstuff
Remotes:
 org/spatial-Stuff
```

However the `pkgdown.yaml` workflow that is run upon pushes (created from `usethis::use_pkgdown_github_pages()`) errors with the following message.

Can someone explain if this is user error or some other error? Thanks

```
! error in pak subprocess
Caused by error:
! Could not solve package dependencies:
deps::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* spatialstuff: Can't find package called spatialstuff.
* local::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* any::sessioninfo: dependency conflict
* any::pkgdown: dependency conflict
```

content.text:
The error you are encountering arises from a mismatch between the name of the package as R expects it (`spatialstuff`) and how it is stored in the GitHub repository (`spatial-Stuff`). R package management systems like `pak` or `devtools` are case-sensitive and rely on consistent naming between the DESCRIPTION file and the actual repository.

Here are a few steps you can take to resolve this issue:

1. **Ensure Consistent Naming**: Double-check that the package name used within your R code, particularly in the `DESCRIPTION` file, matches exactly how it should be recognized. However, in this case, if you do not control the remote package's name, this may not be possible.

2. **Use the Correct Repository Reference**: Since your `Remotes` field is correctly pointing to `org/spatial-Stuff`, ensure that this is explicitly defined and accessible. The `Remotes` field should enable `pak` or other installation methods to find and install the package directly from the specified GitHub repository.

3. **Case Sensitivity**: Ensure wherever you reference the package in your R code or other setup files, you maintain the correct casing as defined in the GitHub repository. 

4. **Check Your GitHub Actions Workflow**: Make sure that your GitHub actions workflow is set up to use `pak` and respect the `Remotes` field properly. This might require updating your yaml to ensure that `pak` or `devtools`, depending on what you are using, is used within its capabilities to fetch the package correctly.

5. **Test Locally**: Run your installation and setup locally to ensure that the `Remotes` field and installation steps work correctly in your environment before relying on the GitHub actions workflow.

6. **Potential Workarounds**: If the above do not work, consider using the GitHub URL directly in your script to install the package before other dependencies are built. You can use `devtools::install_github("org/spatial-Stuff")` as a potential workaround in your setup scripts if the `Remotes` field does not resolve the issue.

content.text:
The error you're encountering stems from the fact that the package `spatialstuff` cannot be located by the system because of the discrepancy between the actual repository name and the expected package name.

Here's a breakdown of the situation and how you might resolve it:

1. **Name Discrepancy**: The `DESCRIPTION` file specifies `spatialstuff` as a dependency within `Imports`, expecting it to be available on CRAN or another standard repository with that exact name. However, the real package is located in a GitHub repository with a different naming pattern (`org/spatial-Stuff`).

2. **Remotes Field**: The `Remotes` field in the `DESCRIPTION` file should correctly allow specifying packages that are hosted on GitHub rather than CRAN. However, GitHub repositories sometimes have package names that don't match their repository names.

3. **Resolution by Package Name**: The error might indicate that `pak`, or the package manager used in your workflow, can't resolve `spatialstuff` because it doesn't match the exact name of the package defined within `spatial-Stuff` repository or the installed package name.

Here are steps to potentially resolve this issue:

- **Check Internal Package Naming**: Ensure that the package within `spatial-Stuff` indeed has `Package: spatialstuff` in its own `DESCRIPTION` file. If the actual package name differs (e.g., `spatial-Stuff`), you'll need to reference it accordingly.

- **Update Remotes Syntax**: Modify the `Remotes` field to correctly align with the actual repository structure, ensuring there are no typos or casing issues:
  
  ```r
  Remotes:
    org/spatial-Stuff
  ```

- **Explicit Installation**: Ensure that your setup is properly installing the GitHub package before attempting to build, or use the correct case sensitivity when installing it manually in your workflow script.

- **Workaround with GitHub URLs**: Another option, though less ideal, is to specify the GitHub URL explicitly in your scripts or workflows to circumvent package name issues. This can be useful if you have direct control over the installation method:
  
  ```r
  pak::pkg_install("org/spatial-Stuff")
  ```

- **CI/CD Adjustments**: If using CI/CD (such as GitHub Actions), ensure your workflow file has an appropriate step to install the package from GitHub directly using `remotes::install_github("org/spatial-Stuff")` before the job checks dependencies and builds your package.

This naming discrepancy between repositories and `DESCRIPTION` entries is a common issue with GitHub-hosted R packages, particularly when automating installations and builds. Adjusting your approach to installing these dependencies is key to overcoming this challenge.

content.text:
You are assessing a submitted answer on a given task based on a criterion.
[BEGIN DATA]
***
[Task]: I see:

```
Error:
! promise already under evaluation: recursive default argument reference or earlier problems?
```

When evaluating the function returned by this function:

```
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, chat = chat) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

How can I fix it?
***
[Submission]: The problem you're encountering is due to the way default arguments in R are evaluated. In the function returned by `generate`, the argument `chat` is set to have a default value that is also named `chat`, leading to a recursive reference. This circular reference causes the "promise already under evaluation" error.

To fix this issue, you need to ensure that the default value and the parameter name don't cause recursive evaluation. Heres how you can modify your code:

```r
generate <- function(chat_instance = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, chat = NULL) {
    # Use the provided chat instance, or fall back to the default one
    if (is.null(chat)) {
      ch <- chat_instance$clone()
    } else {
      ch <- chat$clone()
    }
    
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

Key changes made:
1. **Rename both the outer and inner default argument names to avoid confusion**: The outer function's default argument is named `chat_instance` to be clear and distinct from the generated functions argument.
2. **Use conditional logic inside the inner function**: Check if the `chat` argument is `NULL` (i.e., not provided during the function call) and use the `chat_instance` as the default.

This should resolve your issue by avoiding the recursive reference problem.
***
[Criterion]: It can be fixed by changing the name of the `chat` argument in one of the functions or assigning the `chat` object in the outer function to a different variable name internally and then supplying that renamed object as the default to the inner function.
***

messages.content:
I see:

```
Error:
! promise already under evaluation: recursive default argument reference or earlier problems?
```

When evaluating the function returned by this function:

```
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, chat = chat) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

How can I fix it?

content.text:
The error message you're seeing, `promise already under evaluation: recursive default argument reference or earlier problems`, typically indicates that there is a conflict with the lazy evaluation of arguments in R. Specifically, it's an issue when an argument is evaluated within its own default definition or is being evaluated recursively in a way that's unexpected.

In your code, you are using the default argument `chat = chat` in the inner anonymous function returned by `generate()`. This can create issues because `chat` is being referred to as both the function argument and the parent function's parameter, causing ambiguity.

To fix this error, you can eliminate the default value for `chat` in the inner function, or you can rename the default argument to avoid shadowing. Heres how you can adjust your code:

```r
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, inner_chat = chat) {
    # Use the new argument name 'inner_chat' instead of 'chat'
    ch <- inner_chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

By renaming the argument `chat` inside your anonymous function to `inner_chat`, you avoid the conflict caused by using the same name for both the parameter and the argument. The change clarifies to R which `chat` you are referring to in each context, resolving your error.

input.content:
The error message you're seeing, `promise already under evaluation: recursive default argument reference or earlier problems`, typically indicates that there is a conflict with the lazy evaluation of arguments in R. Specifically, it's an issue when an argument is evaluated within its own default definition or is being evaluated recursively in a way that's unexpected.

In your code, you are using the default argument `chat = chat` in the inner anonymous function returned by `generate()`. This can create issues because `chat` is being referred to as both the function argument and the parent function's parameter, causing ambiguity.

To fix this error, you can eliminate the default value for `chat` in the inner function, or you can rename the default argument to avoid shadowing. Heres how you can adjust your code:

```r
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, inner_chat = chat) {
    # Use the new argument name 'inner_chat' instead of 'chat'
    ch <- inner_chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

By renaming the argument `chat` inside your anonymous function to `inner_chat`, you avoid the conflict caused by using the same name for both the parameter and the argument. The change clarifies to R which `chat` you are referring to in each context, resolving your error.

When evaluating the function returned by this function:

```
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, chat = chat) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

How can I fix it?
***
[Submission]: The error message you're encountering suggests that there's a problem with how the `chat` argument is being used in your nested function. Specifically, it seems like there's a recursive reference or a problem with default argument evaluation in the returned function.

In your code, the default value for the `chat` parameter of the inner function is `chat`, which is derived from the outer function's parameter. This structure can lead to issues since default arguments in R are lazily evaluated. When the inner function is called, it tries to evaluate the default value for `chat`, which involves using the already-evaluated outer `chat`, causing recursion or unnecessary reassessment.

To fix this issue, you can refactor the code to remove the default argument reference and ensure the `chat` object is properly encapsulated without leading to confusion. Here's a modified version of your code:

```r
generate <- function(chat_provider = ellmer::chat_claude) {
  function(input, chat = NULL) {
    if (is.null(chat)) {
      chat <- chat_provider()
    }
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

### Explanation:

1. **Change the parameter name:** I changed the outer function's parameter from `chat` to `chat_provider` to avoid symbol clashes.

2. **Lazy evaluation handlings:** Inside the inner function, we explicitly check if `chat` is `NULL` and if so, call `chat_provider()` to obtain a new chat instance. This allows the outer `chat_provider` to only be called when necessary and avoids any default argument reference issues.

3. **Retain Functionality:** The returned function still attempts to clone the `chat` object and perform the chat operation, maintaining your intended behavior.

This refactoring should solve the recursion problem and clarify the separation of the outer and inner function scopes and their dependencies.

To translate the provided `rlang::abort()` call into a `cli::cli_abort()` call with proper pluralization, you can use the pluralization features of `cli::cli_abort()` and string interpolation. Heres how you can do it:

```r
cli::cli_abort(c(
  "The workflow has argument{?s} to be tuned that {?is/are} missing some parameter object{?s}: {missing_params}.",
  i = "{.val {missing_params}} {are_missing} the parameter object{?s}."
), 
params = pset$id[!params],
missing_params = paste0("'", params, "'", collapse = ", "),
are_missing = ifelse(length(params) > 1, "are", "is")
)
```

Here's a breakdown of how the pluralization is handled:
- `{?s}`: Adds an 's' if the length of `params` is not 1.
- `{?is/are}`: Chooses "is" if singular, "are" if plural.
- `{missing_params}`: Interpolates the list of missing parameters.
- `{.val {missing_params}}`: Formats the missing parameters for emphasis.
- `{are_missing}`: Uses "is" or "are" based on the number of items.

To translate the provided `rlang::abort()` call into a `cli::cli_abort()` call with proper pluralization, you can use the pluralization features of `cli::cli_abort()` and string interpolation. Heres how you can do it:

```r
cli::cli_abort(c(
  "The workflow has argument{?s} to be tuned that {?is/are} missing some parameter object{?s}: {missing_params}.",
  i = "{.val {missing_params}} {are_missing} the parameter object{?s}."
), 
params = pset$id[!params],
missing_params = paste0("'", params, "'", collapse = ", "),
are_missing = ifelse(length(params) > 1, "are", "is")
)
```

Here's a breakdown of how the pluralization is handled:
- `{?s}`: Adds an 's' if the length of `params` is not 1.
- `{?is/are}`: Chooses "is" if singular, "are" if plural.
- `{missing_params}`: Interpolates the list of missing parameters.
- `{.val {missing_params}}`: Formats the missing parameters for emphasis.
- `{are_missing}`: Uses "is" or "are" based on the number of items.

samples.input:
I see this warning and error when I launch my shiny app:

```
Listening on http://127.0.0.1:3516
Warning: Error in $: Can't read output 'plot'
  46: <Anonymous>
  45: signalCondition
  44: signal_abort
  43: rlang::abort
  42: $.shinyoutput
  40: server [#2]
   3: runApp
   2: print.shiny.appobj
   1: <Anonymous>
Error in output$plot : Can't read output 'plot'
```

Here's the app's code:

```
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")
  )

# Create a reactive function to filter the data based on user input
ckd_condition <- reactive({
  input$condition
})

visit_threshold <- reactive({
  input$visit_threshold
})

filtered_data <- reactive({
  Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
    filter(CKD_STAGE == ckd_condition, VISIT_COUNT > visit_threshold)
})

# Create a linear model and visualization
output$plot <- renderPlot({
  validate(
    need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
    need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
  )
                                 # Filter the data based on the user's input
  data <- filtered_data()
  
                                 # Create a linear model
  lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
  
                                 # Create a plot of the linear model
  ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
    geom_point() + 
    geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
    labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
})

# Create a dropdown menu for the user to select the CKD condition level
# and a numeric input field for the visit threshold
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("condition", "Select CKD Condition:", c("CKD 3", "CKD 4", "CKD 5", "ESRD")),
      numericInput("visit_threshold", "Minimum Visit Count:", value = 5, min = 0)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("plot")
    )
  )
)

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = function(input, output) {
  output$plot
})
```

How do I fix it?

```
    validate(
      need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),

                                   # Filter the data based on the user's input

                                   # Create a linear model

                                   # Create a plot of the linear model

      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```

content.text:
The error message you're encountering indicates that the `server` function in your Shiny app is not correctly defined. In a Shiny app, the server function should handle the reactive programming aspects, and this function should define how inputs affect outputs. Your current server function only includes `output$plot`, which is not how you include server logic.

To solve this issue, you need to define the `server` function properly and include the code necessary for the `output$plot` render. Here's a corrected version of the code:

```r
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")
  )

# Define the UI
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("condition", "Select CKD Condition:", c("CKD 3", "CKD 4", "CKD 5", "ESRD")),
      numericInput("visit_threshold", "Minimum Visit Count:", value = 5, min = 0)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("plot")
    )
  )
)

# Define the server
server <- function(input, output, session) {
  # Create a reactive function to filter the data based on user input
  ckd_condition <- reactive({
    input$condition
  })
  
  visit_threshold <- reactive({
    input$visit_threshold
  })
  
  filtered_data <- reactive({
    Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
      filter(CKD_STAGE == ckd_condition(), VISIT_COUNT > visit_threshold())
  })
  
  # Create a linear model and visualization
  output$plot <- renderPlot({
    validate(
      need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
      need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
    )
    
    # Filter the data based on the user's input
    data <- filtered_data()
    
    # Create a linear model
    lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
    
    # Create a plot of the linear model
    ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```

### Key Changes Made:
1. **Server Function**: The code defining the plot output is now within a `server` function, which correctly associates `output$plot` with `renderPlot({ ... })` logic.
2. **Reactive Expressions**: I used `()` in `ckd_condition()` and `visit_threshold()` to correctly call the reactive expressions when required.
3. **Error Messages**: Double-check the validation messages to ensure appropriate feedback when inputs are not provided or are invalid. 

With these changes, your Shiny app should now correctly set up the `output$plot` and respond to user inputs as intended.

```r
)

server <- function(input, output, session) {
  # Create a reactive function to filter the data based on user input
  ckd_condition <- reactive({

    )
    
    # Filter the data based on the user's input
    data <- filtered_data()
    
    # Create a linear model
    lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
    
    # Create a plot of the linear model
    ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```

input.content:
The error message you're encountering indicates that the `server` function in your Shiny app is not correctly defined. In a Shiny app, the server function should handle the reactive programming aspects, and this function should define how inputs affect outputs. Your current server function only includes `output$plot`, which is not how you include server logic.

To solve this issue, you need to define the `server` function properly and include the code necessary for the `output$plot` render. Here's a corrected version of the code:

```r
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")
  )

# Define the UI
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("condition", "Select CKD Condition:", c("CKD 3", "CKD 4", "CKD 5", "ESRD")),
      numericInput("visit_threshold", "Minimum Visit Count:", value = 5, min = 0)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("plot")
    )
  )
)

# Define the server
server <- function(input, output, session) {
  # Create a reactive function to filter the data based on user input
  ckd_condition <- reactive({
    input$condition
  })
  
  visit_threshold <- reactive({
    input$visit_threshold
  })
  
  filtered_data <- reactive({
    Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
      filter(CKD_STAGE == ckd_condition(), VISIT_COUNT > visit_threshold())
  })
  
  # Create a linear model and visualization
  output$plot <- renderPlot({
    validate(
      need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
      need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
    )
    
    # Filter the data based on the user's input
    data <- filtered_data()
    
    # Create a linear model
    lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
    
    # Create a plot of the linear model
    ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```

### Key Changes Made:
1. **Server Function**: The code defining the plot output is now within a `server` function, which correctly associates `output$plot` with `renderPlot({ ... })` logic.
2. **Reactive Expressions**: I used `()` in `ckd_condition()` and `visit_threshold()` to correctly call the reactive expressions when required.
3. **Error Messages**: Double-check the validation messages to ensure appropriate feedback when inputs are not provided or are invalid. 

With these changes, your Shiny app should now correctly set up the `output$plot` and respond to user inputs as intended.

The issue you're encountering is due to a misunderstanding of how the server function in Shiny works and how reactivity is handled. The primary problem is in how the `server` function is structured. You need to define reactive expressions and outputs inside the `server` function. The `output$plot` object should be created inside the `server` function, and the reactive expressions should be defined inside as well. Let me show you how to fix it.

Here is the corrected version of your Shiny app code:

```r
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")

# Define UI for the application
```
